author: sky.cactus
content: The problem is that we really need a whole client so the EIP can define just a change, and not need to define all of the related data structures.

author: gcolvin
content:
EIP authors are responsible for specifying their intent to the client teams. They are encouraged to (and usually do) maintain a reference implementation.  That's a lot of work.  Requiring them to translate their work into a PR on the Reference Specification as well is a big ask.

Regardless, what goes live is what defines the consensus protocol, and that amounts to a number of PRs by client teams who understood the EIP well enough to make them.  I think the team maintaining the Reference Specification can be trusted to do the same.

And none of this really affects the EIP Editors.  The technical quality of the specification is not for us to judge.
